title: 111_s3810
content: The Act is titled the "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" and includes a restriction on participation in offshore oil and gas leasing. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" mandates that leases for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf include a certification requirement to ensure compliance with Iran sanctions. Failure to certify or providing false information may result in lease cancellation. Additionally, the Secretary of the Interior is required to disclose information related to these certifications. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" requires leases for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf to include a provision for disclosing any involvement in energy-related ventures outside Iran with blocked individuals. Failure to comply may lead to lease cancellation. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" mandates lease holders to disclose any ties to blocked individuals or entities. Failure to disclose or providing false information may result in lease cancellation. The Secretary of the Interior has the authority to cancel a lease if a person fails to disclose required information or provides false information. The Secretary can waive this requirement on a case-by-case basis if it is in the national interest, and must report any waivers granted. Additionally, the Secretary must report to congressional committees any lease cancellations, providing reasons for the action. The Secretary of the Interior can cancel a lease if required information is not disclosed or false information is provided. The appropriate congressional committees must be informed of any lease cancellations, with reasons provided. Definitions for terms like "appropriate congressional committees" and "person" are also provided in this section. The Act will end 30 days after the President certifies that Iran has stopped supporting terrorism, pursuing weapons of mass destruction, and no longer poses a threat to US national security or allies.
